articles.title: ⭐ The State of Vue.js Report 2025
articles.description: Created with the support of the Vue and Nuxt teams, this is no mere collection of statistics and charts (though there’s plenty of both) but a thorough update on the state of both projects and an interview with Evan You on Vue (and Vite's) latest developments. Essential reading for any Vue, Vite, or Nuxt user and a one-stop shop for understanding Vue and Nuxt as they stand right now.
articles.author: Monterail

articles.title: War Story: The Hardest Bug I Ever Debugged
articles.description: A former engineer on the Google Docs team tells the tale of a bizarre error that afflicted Google Docs out of the blue about ten years ago. It’s a gnarly one and was only solved due to his swift access to V8’s engineers. If you’ve ever spent hours digging into a bug, you’ll feel glad you weren’t dealing with this one!
articles.author: Jacob Voytko

articles.title: Next.js's Recent Middleware Security Woes
articles.description: Last weekend, a new version of Next.js landed to resolve a security vulnerability that could allow middleware to be bypassed. Self-hosted Next.js deployments need to be upgraded immediately. The news led to many responses including deep dives into the vulnerability and criticism of how it was all handled.
articles.author: Lee Robinson (Vercel)

articles.title: Writing a Tiny Undo/Redo Stack in JavaScript
articles.description: You might prefer to lean upon an established approach (using Immer patches perhaps), but if you want to implement something small yourself, this might help.
articles.author: Julik Tarkhanov

articles.title: Land Ahoy: Leaving the Sea of Nodes
articles.description: A deeply technical post from a core member of the V8 JavaScript engine team that explains the limitations of Turbofan, one of V8’s optimizing compilers. If you don’t care for the internals of how your JavaScript is compiled and run, just be assured the V8 team is working to make it run even faster.
articles.author: Darius Mercadier (V8)

articles.title: Mission jQuery Zero: How FreeAgent Removed jQuery From Its App
articles.description: Despite popular developer sentiment, jQuery’s prevalence on the Web continues to be significant but “sometimes legends need to retire”.
articles.author: Colin Gemmell

articles.title: ▶  React Query API Design: Lessons Learned
articles.description: You might know Dominik for all his work on React Query, TanStack Router, and his epic React Query - The Bad Parts series. Here, he walks us through the design choices made while building React Query and shares lessons and mistakes valuable to anyone building their own libraries. (30 minutes.)
articles.author: Dominik Dorfmeister (TkDodo)

articles.title: Deploying a Next.js App to Production on Any Server
articles.description: A popular article from last year that’s been updated for 2025 and Next.js 15.
articles.author: Kamrannetic

articles.title: Babylon.js 8.0: Microsoft's JavaScript 3D Engine
articles.description: 8.0 adds support for improved ‘image based lighting’ and ‘area lights’ for environmental lighting and shadows, extra control of the render pipeline, and a new lightweight viewer. And, as always, they have ▶️ a short video showing it all off.
articles.author: Microsoft

articles.title: 🤖 An MCP Server for Playwright and Browser Automation
articles.description: MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers enable certain LLM-based agents (such as Claude, Claude Code, and Cursor) to perform actions on a system outside of their usual sandbox. This new project from Microsoft enables such LLMs to interact with browsers via Playwright.
articles.author: Microsoft

articles.title: Lexical 0.29: An Easy-to-Extend Text Editor Framework from Meta
articles.description: A text editor framework built by Meta with extensibility, accessibility, and cross platform support in mind (there’s even a Swift variant for iOS). There’s a live playground if you want to give it a try.
articles.author: Meta / Facebook

articles.title: 🔎 Fuzzball: Fuzzy String Matching Library
articles.description: To tackle those cases where what’s typed isn’t quite what’s wanted. There’s a neat tree-themed Web-based demo.
articles.author: Nolan

articles.description: Cloudflare has done some work to bring the URLPattern URL matching API to Node.js and Cloudflare Workers.
🤖 If you haven't checked out Google's Gemini AI tool recently (or ever), it now supports generating HTML, JavaScript, and React code in a 'canvas' mode for building components on the fly.
🤖 MCP Node.js Debugger is an attempt to make Node's debugger more accessible to third-party AI coding tools (such as Cursor or Claude Code).
📊 Is Vite faster than Turbopack? "Well, it depends."
Bun v1.2.7 – Bun's HTTP server now has built-in support for reading and writing cookies using a Map-like API.
Node v18.20.8 (LTS) – Note that Node 18 reaches 'end-of-life' next month.
Sinon 20.0 – Test spies, stubs and mocks library.
pnpm 10.7, Babel 7.27.0, ESLint 9.23.0, Neutralinojs 6.0, Material UI v7

articles.title: The <select> Element Can Now Be Customized with CSS
articles.description: There’s now an accessible, standardized way to create styleable <select> elements — thanks to appearance: base-select. Adam shares how this has been “many years in the making” and after “many hours of engineering and collaborative specification work” we now have a rich component that won’t break in older browsers. Here’s a closer look at how things play in Chrome (the first to implement support), and how to use it.
articles.author: Adam Argyle

articles.title: How to Think About Baseline and Polyfills
articles.description: Despite polyfills not being included as part of the Baseline project, Baseline can still help bring some nuance to the decision making around whether or not to use them.
articles.author: Jeremy Wagner

articles.title: Support Logical Shorthands in CSS
articles.description: The CSS Working Group recently resolved to add a size shorthand for setting both the width and height of an element. Many people asked about using it to set the ‘logical’ inline-size and block-size properties instead. But ‘logical shorthands’ have been stalled in the working group for years (since 2017!). Miriam asks if we get them unstuck?
articles.author: Miriam Suzanne

articles.title: Minding the Gaps: A New Way to Draw Separators in CSS
articles.description: Explains CSS gap decorations, a new proposal being worked on (and seeking feedback) for adding and extending fine-tune control over gap decorations.
articles.author: Babbitt & Brosset (Microsoft)

articles.title: Revisiting CSS border-image
articles.description: A deep dive into the powerful border-image property and how it can be used in various creative ways: “By slicing, repeating, and outsetting images, you can create intricate borders, decorative elements, and even dynamic overlays with minimal code”.
articles.author: Andy Clarke

articles.title: The Bare Minimum You Need to Enable View Transitions on Your Site
articles.description: View transitions are a solid way to make your site feel more dynamic and engaging when folks are navigating between pages. Here’s the basics for getting started.
articles.author: Amit Merchant

articles.title: Layered Text Headers
articles.description: Applying a stroke effect to text across all browsers is possible, but as Chris points out it makes use of a center-aligned look which “looks like 💩” (his words). However, the paint-order property may be worth a look as part of a solution for achieving a similar look.
articles.author: Chris Coyier

articles.title: Previewing Content Changes in Your Work with document.designMode
articles.description: A look at several use cases for document.designMode and how it can be used to preview content changes, do basic content editing, and improve team collaboration.
articles.author: Victor Ayomipo

articles.title: Best Practices for Cognitive Accessibility in Web Design
articles.description: Lots of good practical advice here, covering ways to improve your website’s cognitive accessibility.
articles.author: Caitlin de Rooij

articles.title: An MCP Server for Playwright and Browser Automation
articles.description: MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers enable certain LLM-based agents (such as Claude, Claude Code, and Cursor) to perform actions on a system outside of their usual sandbox. This new project from Microsoft enables such LLMs to interact with Web pages in a structured way (much as Playwright lets you do from Python or JavaScript code).
articles.author: Microsoft

articles.title: CASCII: A Web-Based ASCII and Unicode Diagram Builder
articles.description: Imagine something like MS Paint but for text-based drawing. You can switch between ASCII and Unicode modes and enable a background grid for alignment. Export directly to clipboard or in Base64.
articles.author: Caspar Wylie

articles.title: Konva: A JavaScript 2D Canvas Library
articles.description: The native API for Canvas elements is pretty good, but Konva is a popular abstraction that sits on top and provides a more structured way to work with shapes, styling, events, animations, and more (lots of demos with code). It also has extra integration libraries for Vue, Svelte and React.
articles.author: Konva

articles.title: Reveal.js 5.2: The HTML Presentation Framework
articles.description: Brings elegant presentations to anyone with a Web browser. v5.2 adds the ability to trigger ‘lightboxes’ where viewers can see images and videos in a way where they stand out more.
articles.author: Hakim El Hattab

articles.title: Parvus 3.0: Accessible Lightbox with No Dependencies
articles.description: I love how it says not to use overlays on web pages but if you have to, use this! There’s a CodePen example.
articles.author: Benjamin de Oostfrees

articles.title: Fancy Components: A Growing Library of Ready-to-Use Animated React Components
articles.description: Includes a whole slew of components for doing various text animations, along with others for backgrounds, physics-related animations, SVG filters, and more. Try them out here.
articles.author: Daniel Petho

articles.title: StringTune: The JavaScript Library Born from a Design Agency’s Workflow
articles.description: A look at how to make use of this flexible JavaScript library for animations, smooth scrolling, and interactive effects. npm package.
articles.author: Fiddle.Digital
